_header: Jesu sweet is the love of Thee / nothing so sweet may be
Note: See also 5077 in which this piece has been combined with 5075
Subjects: hymns, to Christ; Christ, hymns to
_description: An expansion of the hymn, ‘Iesu dulcis memoria’ — fifty monorhyming quatrains

BLHar2253.First Lines:
Iesu suete is þe loue of þenoþing so suete may
                    be…
BLHar2253.Last Lines:
…bote ioie & blisse ant lykyngsuete iesu þare to vs
                    bryng

GULHun512.First Lines:
IHesu swete is þe loue of þeeNoon oþir þing so
                    swete may be…
GULHun512.Last Lines:
…Þanne haue I þi wille al wrouȝtÞat hauest
                    me ful dere bouȝt
GULHun512.Editions:
Brown,  Carleton Fairchild,
                        ed.  
             Religious Lyrics of the XIV Century.
         Oxford: Clarendon, 1924. 2nd ed., rev.: G. V. Smithers, Oxford,
            1952: 111-12.

Chicago31.First Lines:
Ihesu swete his þe loue of þeNon oþur þyng so
                    swete may beAl þat I may wyt henn seTo halwn aswetnes lord to
                    þeNo song nys murworNo no yoth in herte
                    blysfulore…
Chicago31.Last Lines:
…Hou long schal here beþere I pe þe tasy wyt henn
                    se
Chicago31.Note:
In this MS, 80 lines in couplets, aa (Brown  and  Robbins (1943)
XCarleton Fairchild Brown,   and  Rossell Hope Robbins.  
             The Index of Middle English Verse.
         New York: Printed for the Index Society by Columbia University Press,
            1943 says 100
                    but perhaps in another MS); may be incomplete here since no ‘amen’
                    at end, followed by pastedown so last leaf of MS. Note last line very difficult
                    to read and may be subject to correction from an edition.
Chicago31.Editions:
Robbins,  Rossell Hope. 
             “Two Fourteenth-Century Mystical Poems.” 
             Modern Language Review
         35 (1940): 320-9: 325-7.
